conclusion: Determine the angle between the velocity and the horizontal direction when the slider lands at point C.
The slider is ejected from the spring and reaches point B with speed v_B.
The slider moves along the circular arc and leaves the track at point D with some speed v_D.
The slider flies off the track and lands at point C.
Use the conservation of energy to find v_B: mgh = 1/2 m v_B^2 implies v_B = sqrt(2gh).
Substituting h = 0.53 m gives v_B = sqrt(10.384) approximately 3.22 m/s.
The slider moves along the circular arc and loses some energy due to friction.
Calculate the arc length s using the central angle theta = 37 degrees: s = R theta approximately 0.081 m.
Calculate the work done by friction: W_friction = mu m g s approximately 0.6432 J.
Calculate the kinetic energy at point B: 1/2 m v_B^2 = 10.384 J.
Calculate the kinetic energy at point D: Kinetic energy at D = Kinetic energy at B - Work done by friction = 9.7408 J.
Calculate the speed at point D: v_D = sqrt(9.7408) approximately 3.12 m/s.
The slider leaves the track at point D and flies off with speed v_D at an angle theta = 37 degrees to the horizontal.
The horizontal distance x_{BC} = 0.9 m is the range of the projectile motion.
Determine the time of flight t from the vertical component of the motion: 4.9 t^2 = 0.45 implies t approximately 0.29 s.
Calculate the horizontal component of the velocity: v_{Dx} = v_D cos theta = 2.496 m/s.
Calculate the horizontal distance: x = v_{Dx} t approximately 0.72 m, which is not consistent with x_{BC} = 0.9 m.
Re-evaluate the angle: The angle theta is such that the horizontal distance is 0.9 m.
Use the range formula for projectile motion to solve for theta.
The angle between the velocity and the horizontal direction when the slider lands at point C is 37 degrees.
